Award.AwardTitle: Sensitive Dual Mode Microfluidic Optomechanical Analysis of Biomolecules

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to harness the light radiation pressure to excite extremely high frequency mechanical vibrations in a microfluidic optomechanical resonator and then apply the microfluidic optomechanical resonator in analyzing biomolecular interactions where both optical and mechanical detection methods will be employed. Different from the state-of-the-art in vibrating microfluidic devices, the microfluidic optomechanical resonator is electrode-less. Both excitation and interrogation of the vibrations are accomplished optically, which breaks the electrical-impedance limit typically seen in current acoustical actuation techniques and enables the microfluidic optomechanical resonator to operate at the acoustical X band (10 GHz). In the project, the microfluidic optomechanical resonator will be analyzed mechanically and optically. Then the microfluidic optomechanical resonator will be fabricated and characterized. Finally, the microfluidic optomechanical resonator will be used to study protein-small molecule interaction and protein-protein interaction where both the mass and the conformational change of biomolecules can be detected.

If successful, the results will lead to a fundamental understanding of optomechanics in liquid and a new type of biochemical sensor based on cavity optomechanics. They pave the way to simultaneous acoustical and optical detection of analytes in liquid, which allows for more detailed analysis of biomolecular interactions. Meanwhile, they open a door to many other applications in non-solid phases of matter such as high-resolution ultrasound imaging and optomechanical excitation of superfluids.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project is to develop a sensor that combines the optical and acoustic detection on the same device. The dual-mode optical and acoustic detection work as human eyes and ears that provides complementary information about molecules, particles, cells, as well as tissues.

In the center of our technology is the optofluidic ring resonator, which basically is a thin-walled glass capillary. The wall can be as thin as a few microns. The circular cross section of the capillary form the ring resonator. Optical light can circulate along the capillary circumference and thus can exert force on the wall. Due to the thin wall, only small amount of optical power is needed to make the wall of the capillary to vibrate in an acoustic mode. Binding of molecules/particles to the wall will cause the optical mode and acoustic mode to change simultaneously. Therefore, the ring resonator is able to detect both optical and acoustic properties of the molecules/particles. In turn, acoustic wave impinged on the ring resonator will deform the capillary. Due to the thin wall, deformation can be large even with a very weak acoustic wave. The deformation (along with the refractive index change in the wall caused by acoustic wave pressure) will lead to a change in the optical mode. Therefore, the ring resonator can also be used to detect the acoustic wave optically.

In our project, we first carried out theoretical calculation to estimate how much the sensing signal is for a layer of biomolecules deposited onto the surface and for an acoustic wave at different frequencies impinged on the ring resonator. Then we fabricated and characterized the optofluidic ring resonator. Finally, we carried out biodetection and acoustic wave detection. We found that:

1. for biosensing, the ring resonator has a mechanical detection limit for biomolecules on the order of tens of pico-gram per millimeter squared. This detection limit agrees with the optical detection limit. More importantly, our sensor is able to perform all biosensing in the presence of liquid without losing its mechanical sensitivity. This is one of important features of our ring resonator. Usually the mechanical vibration (or mode) is lost when the device is immersed in liquid.

2. for acoustic wave detection, the ring resonator has a detection limit on the order of tens of milli-Pascal per square root of Hz, which put our ring resonator one of the most sensitive acoustic wave detectors. In particular, the acoustic wave detection can be performed in air (without gel or water as the interfacing media).

We have published a few peer-reviewed papers based on the outcomes from the project. One patent was also filed. In addition, a company is being formed to commercialize the dual-mode sensor for both biosensing and acoustic wave detection.
